sample.name: GT cfDNA extracts 222
endoscopy_result: Extensive vascular obliteration to distal transverse and beyond. degree of rectal sparing likely related to topical therapy. UCEIS 2 +0 +0 = 2.
pathology_result:
Examination shows a confluent colitis in all three biopsy sites with acute and chronic inflammation, cryptitis and crypt abscess formation. No granulomas identified.

No nuclear inclusions are identified. No dysplasia or malignancy are identified.

The features are those of active ulcerative colitis in keeping with the clinical history.

endoscopy_result: There was moderately severe inflammation to the distal sigmoid and beyond. UCEIS = 2+2+2 = 6/8. There was a degree of rectal sparing and I suspect this represents recent topical 5-ASA therapy. Representative biopsies taken.
pathology_result:
The biopsies from the sigmoid colon are colonic mucosa, much of which shows mild architectural distortion but no inflammation.  Other fragments, however, have a fairly diffuse increase in acute and chronic inflammation in the lamina propria with loss of the normal inflammatory cell gradient.  There is cryptitis and crypt abscess formation and a degree of crypt withering.  There are no granulomas.  CMV inclusions are not seen.

The rectal biopsies are of colonic mucosa which shows mild architectural
distortion in several of the fragments.  There is very little in the way of
inflammation with small foci of active lamina propria inflammation being seen and occasional damaged crypts.  No granulomas or CMV inclusions are seen.

Comment
The changes seen in this sigmoidoscopic set of biopsies are mild and rather patchy.  I note that we have no previous biopsies from this patient on record but Trak would indicate that the diagnosis was made elsewhere.  The relative patchiness of the inflammation may be secondary to drug treatment, not being typical of ulcerative colitis.  The relative prominence of crypt withering, however, does raise the possibility that there is an infective element to the process.  Overall, the appearances are most likely to represent partially treated active ulcerative colitis but superadded infection should be excluded.

endoscopy_result: At least left sided moderate to severe colitis - gastroscope passed to distal descending (50cm) with multiple biopsies on withdrawal. Proximal limit of inflammation not seen so probably extends further. Foul smelling flatus. Appearance suggestive of UC if infection excluded.
pathology_result:
All the submitted fragments are inflamed to a similar degree, and the inflammation is histologically diffuse. Microscopic examination shows moderate active chronic inflammation. There is distortion of the glandular architecture associated with elongation/hyperplasia of glands. There is cryptitis and there are crypt abscesses. No granulomata are identified. There is no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy.

Comment: There is diffuse moderate active chronic inflammation in all the submitted biopsy fragments. Infectious aetiologies should be excluded; however, the pattern of inflammatory activity strongly suggests distal active IBD, UC-type favoured.

baseline_gi_symptoms_desc: opening bowels up to five times a day, loose
ct_result:
Colitis centred on splenic flexure appears slightly more extensive and severe when compared with MR dated April 2021. Is diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease secure? Distribution would fit with ischaemia. No toxic dilatation, perforation, obstruction or collection.
Lung bases clear. Prior cholecystectomy but other abdominal viscera unremarkable. IUCD appropriately sited. No ascites or pelvic masses. No nodal enlargement or destructive skeletal finding.

Comment:
Left sided colitis. No current complication.

baseline_gi_symptoms_desc: Fevers for last 2 weeks,Nausea and vomiting, struggling to eat and drink
endoscopy_result: Moderate to severe colitis up to and beyond level of insertion at 50cm with some slightly more mild appearances in rectum (likely due to topical treatments). UCEIS 2,2,3. Biopsies including for CMV sent urgently.
pathology_result:
Sigmoid colon biopsies: Sections show large bowel-type mucosa with mild crypt architectural distortion in the form of crypt loss, moderate patchy chronic inflammation within the lamina propria and moderate active inflammation in the form of cryptitis and crypt abscess formation. CMV inclusions are identified morphologically and this is confirmed on immunohistochemistry for CMV. There is no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy. Granulomas are not seen.

Rectosigmoid biopsies: Sections show large bowel-type mucosa with mild crypt architectural distortion in the form of crypt loss, moderate patchy chronic inflammation within the lamina propria and cryptitis and crypt abscess formation which appears more severe than that seen in part 1. CMV inclusions are identified morphologically and this is confirmed on immunohistochemistry for CMV. There is no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy. Granulomas are not seen.

Rectal biopsies: Sections show large bowel-type mucosa with minimal, focal crypt architectural distortion. There is a very slight increase in chronic inflammatory cells within the lamina propria however no evidence of cryptitis or crypt abscess formation.

Comment: The appearances are those of moderate to severely active colitis predominantly affecting the rectosigmoid junction. The rectum is only minimally involved although as noted in the clinical history this may be a result of topical treatment. CMV inclusions are present in the biopsies from all 3 sites. There is no evidence of dysplasia. The appearances would be in keeping with moderately to severely active distal ulcerative colitis with CMV infection.

Biopsies from proximal sigmoid, rectosigmoid and rectum - Moderately to severely active colitis; relative rectal sparing; CMV positive
ct_result:
Acute confluent colitis of the transverse colon to the rectum on background of chronic inflammatory change. No obstruction, dilatation of features of toxic megacolon. No evidence of perforation. Normal bowel wall enhancement.

Appendicolith at the base of a mildly dilated appendix (7mm), no additional signs of active appendicitis.

Unremarkable appearance of the small bowel.

Multiple small nodes scattered throughout the mesentery and upper para-aortic nodes (largest measuring 9mm). Large spleen at 17.3cm craniocaudal (15.3cm axially). While some of this could be reactive to the active colitis, a haematology opinion would still be recommended.

Remaining solid upper abdominal viscera are normal.
Normal opacification of the major abdominal vessels including SMA and IMA.
The lung bases are unremarkable.
No sinister or destructive bony abnormality.

Opinoin:
Confluent acute on chronic colitis extending from the transverse colon to the rectum - in keeping with a flare of ulcerative colitis. Small volume of free pelvic fluid but no organised collection. Splenomegaly with several small mesenteric/para-aortic nodes. Haematology opinion recommended.

endoscopy_result: There was moderate rectal erythema and granularity. Above this inflammation more patchy but extended above limit of insertion, plus one area of tiny ulcers/erosions in sigmoid. There was one area in sigmoid with normal vascular pattern but inflammation both proximal and distal to this. Note previous diagnosis of IBDU with right colonic and rectal inflammation. Images today look much improved to those from first procedure in October.
pathology_result:
1. Sigmoid colon: The biopsies from the sigmoid colon show a focal crypt architectural distortion in the form of crypt loss. There is evidence of mucin depletion. There is a patchy, moderate chronic inflammatory infiltrate within the lamina propria. Cryptitis and crypt abscess formation is abundant. Granulomas are not seen and there is no evidence of dysplasia. CMV inclusions are not identified despite use of immunohistochemistry.

2. The biopsies from the rectum show similar changes to those seen in the sigmoid colon however the inflammation is more severe and widespread with no evidence of a patchy distribution. Crypt abscesses and cryptitis are again abundant and there is more prominent crypt architectural distortion. Granulomas are not seen. There is no evidence of dysplasia. CMV inclusions are not identified.

Comment:
The appearances are those of a severely active sigmoid colitis and proctitis. Although this is patchy in the sigmoid, the disease in the rectum is more severe and confluent in its distribution. The patchy distribution may reflect partial treatment given the above clinical information. In the absence of infection the appearances would be in keeping with IBD favouring UC. There is no evidence of dysplasia.

endoscopy_result: Confluent moderate to severe inflammation to the point of insertion and betond. Disease previously restricted to the rectum. Has failed 4 weekly vedolizumab, oral prednisolone, budesonide oral and rectal mesalazine.
pathology_result:
All of these colonic and rectal biopsies are abnormal exhibiting marked crypt architectural distortion with villiform transformation of the mucosal surface.

There is a dense diffuse chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate in the lamina
propria. The changes are most marked in the rectum where there is a greater degree of crypt loss and crypt architectural distortion associated with crypt abscess formation and foci of cryptitis.

Conclusion
The features are those of moderately active chronic ulcerative colitis involving all biopsy sites. There is no evidence of dysplasia.
diagnosis_note: Known UC, symptoms worsening since Feb 2020, particularly in last 3 months
past_medical_history_detail: COPD, hiatus hernia, osteoporosis, stress incontinence

endoscopy_result: Extensive ulceration with large deep ulcers from rectum to proximal descending. beyond this mucosa appears to become more normal.
pathology_result:
The biopsies from the transverse colon are normal. Most of the biopsies in the descending colon are also relatively normal however there is evidence of ulceration with overlying acute inflammatory exudate.

The biopsies from the rectosigmoid junction consist of acute inflammatory exudate only. The biopsies from the sigmoid colon and rectum include intact mucosa exhibiting crypt elongation, crypt architectural distortion, focal goblet cell depletion and focal cryptitis. Crypt abscesses are not seen. There is an associated relatively diffuse moderate increase in chronic inflammatory cells in the lamina propria. There is evidence of ulceration in the rectal biopsies which is associated with organising fibrin. Intravascular fibrin thrombi are also seen in the intact mucosa.

Neither CMV inclusions nor amoeba are identified. Granulomata are not seen. There is no evidence of dysplasia.

Conclusion
While the histological features most likely represent relatively acute IBD (namely UC) the characteristics of ulceration are slightly unusual therefore in my opinion infection should be rigorously excluded in the first instance.
ct_result:
Marked mucosal thickening and oedematous change involving the entire colon, most severe in the sigmoid. Prominent paracolic vascularity particularly on the right side. Appearances are in keeping with a pancolitis. No toxic dilatation or perforation.

Opinion
Pancolitis. Infective or inflammatory etiologies are thought most likely.

endoscopy_result: Splenic flexure reached. Active colitis from anal margin to beyond limit of scope insertion (could see distal transverse also involved). Oedematous, congested and friable mucosa, with spontaneous bleeding but no deep ulceration. (Moderate/Moderate-severe inflammation) The rectal inflammation was less uniform probably due to topical treatment.
pathology_result:
Examination shows mild architectural distortion associated with acute and chronic inflammation, cryptitis and crypt abscess formation. The rectum appears slightly spared compared with the more proximal biopsies but there are some cryptolytic aggregates of macrophages falling short of frank granulomas.

The features are those of active distal ulcerative colitis with milder rectal sparing which may be related to topical treatment. No nuclear inclusions are identified on routine H&E histology.

baseline_gi_symptoms_desc: Reports not well past year, ongoing symptoms with abdominal pain worse after food and moving. Diarrhoea and weight loss.
mri_sb_result:
Comparison is made with previous MRI dated 22/7/20.

Similar distribution to previous with thickening and wall oedema in the proximal jejunum over 60cm. There is some dilatation in the jejunum suggesting proximal stricturing lesions but again this is similar to previous. The wall thickening is less than previous (eg. distal jejunum 3mm wall thickening vs 7mm previously) with less T2 high signal suggestive of some improvement although there remains active disease. Improvement in diffusion restriction also. 
Improvement in the appearances of the fissuring with no evidence of further Crohn's related complications.
Some diffusion restriction in the descending colon - is this patient known to have colonic disease?
Normal solid organs.

Opinion:
Mild disease improvement in degree of oedema and wall thickening but there remains evidence of disease activity, stricturing and prestenotic dilatation.
past_ibd_surgery_detail: Right hemicolectomy March 2004, IC resection for obstruction October 2015; EUA and lay open fistula - Feb 2015..

sample.name: cfDNA extracts 289
baseline_gi_symptoms_desc: 4 weeks of diarrhoea and abdo pain
endoscopy_result:
Confluent inflammation to point of insertion to distal sigmoid
Vascular pattern total loss 2
Mild intraluminal blood 2
No ulcers seen although mucosa obscured by faecal matter
Sigmoid and rectal biopsies for urgent assessment
Impression Likely new IBD favouring UC
pathology_result:
1&2.  All the tissue from both sites show similar appearances.  There is mild crypt architectural distortion with focal crypt dropout.  There is mild cryptitis and crypt abscess formation and a loss of goblet cells.  There is a uniform increase in lymphoplasmacytic inflammation within the lamina propria. Organisms are not seen.  Granulomas are not seen.  There is no evidence of dysplasia.
                                
Comment: Sections show a confluent mildly active colitis affecting the sigmoid colon and rectum.  Granulomas are not seen.  In the absence of infection or drug aetiology and in the correct clinical context the histological appearances would be in keeping with mild to moderately active inflammatory bowel disease favouring ulcerative colitis.
ct_result:
Pan colonic wall thickening with associated vascular injection. The sigmoid colon is moderately distended and measures 5 cm in diameter.  This is the site of maximal distension, relative to this the remainder of the colon is nondistended.  No perforation.  No intra-abdominal free fluid.  Scattered reactive mesenteric nodes.

Hepatic steatosis.  Normal portal vein, spleen, pancreas, nondistended biliary tree and gallbladder, adrenal glands, kidneys, bladder which outlines normally.  Normal retroperitoneum.  Unremarkable small bowel.
Extreme lung bases are normal.  Unremarkable bones.

Opinion:
Pancolitis with no evidence of collection or perforation.

endoscopy_result: There was extensive mucosal obliteration with friability from rectum to the limit of insertion in the proximal descending colon. This was more marked in the descending colon. Highly suspicious of UC.
pathology_result:
All of the fragments are abnormal and show similar histological features. There is a florid and diffuse increase in lymphocytes and plasma cells within the lamina propria, including basal plasmacytosis. This is associated with cryptitis, numerous crypt abscesses, mucin depletion and prominent crypt distortion. No granulomas. Scattered CMV inclusions within endothelial and stromal cells.

Comment:
The apperances are consistent with moderately active IBD, with a pattern and distribution typical of UC. The contribution of CMV infection is uncertain - numbers are relatively small in comparison to the severity of the inflammation, suggesting IBD/UC is the primary pathology.

endoscopy_result: Moderate-severe inflammation (UCEIS 6 - V3B1E2 - if UC confirmed) to limit of insertion in proximal descending and beyond.
pathology_result:
All biopsies from left colon and rectum show similar features. There are features of chronicity with architectural crypt distortion and basal plasmacytosis with a diffuse increase in the number of chronic inflammatory cells in the lamina propria. There is moderate active inflammation with cryptitis and crypt abscesses seen in all three biopsies. Granulomata are not identified and viral inclusions are not seen.

Conclusion
These biopsies show features of moderately active chronic IBD. The distribution and confluence would favour a diagnosis of UC if an infectious aetiology has been rigorously excluded.

endoscopy_result: UCEIS V3B3E2 - 8 to degree of insertion at 40cm. Biopsies taken including CMV. Continue IVMP and counsel for Infliximab.
pathology_result:
Examination shows mild architectural distortion with acute on chronic inflammation, cryptitis and crypt abscess formation. No viral inclusions are identified on H&E and immunohistochemistry for CMV is negative. No dysplasia or malignancy are seen.

The features are those of a moderate to severe active distal colitis in keeping with the clinical diagnosis of ulcerative colitis.

endoscopy_result: Moderate-severe colitis to limit of insertion. More marked in rectum. Confluent erythema with superficial ulcers and loss of vascular pattern throughout. Contact bleeding. UCEIS 7 in rectum and 6 in sigmoid.
pathology_result:
All of the biopsies are abnormal and show similar histological features. There is a florid and diffuse increase in lymphocytes and plasma cells within the lamina propria, including basal plasmacytosis. The fragments also show cryptitis with multiple crypt abscesses, mucin depletion and mild crypt distortion. Granulomas and CMV inclusions are not identified.

Comment: The features are consistent with moderately active IBD. The pattern and distribution of inflammation would favour ulcerative colitis.

antibiotics_detail: Recent 7 days metro and 7 days parmomycin for entamoeba histolytica
medication_comments: 7 days IV steroids vs usual 5 day regime
endoscopy_result: Confluent inflammation from rectum to the limit of inserion and beyond. There was deep ulceration and mucosa was fraible. Simgoid and rectal biopsies taking. UCEIS V2 B2 U3 = 7.
pathology_result:
All of these biopsies are abnormal exhibiting marked crypt architectural
distortion with villiform transformation of the mucosal surface. There are crypt
abscesses and foci of cryptitis associated with focal goblet cell depletion and
a diffuse increase in chronic inflammatory cells in the lamina propria. There is
histological evidence of ulceration biopsies from the sigmoid colon. Neither CMV
inclusion nor granulomata are seen.

Conclusion
The features seen in these biopsies are those of at least moderately active
chronic ulcerative colitis. There is no evidence of dysplasia in these biopsies.

endoscopy_result: There was extensive inflammation within the rectum with complete obliteration of the vascular pattern and large ulcers. The inflammation extended to 30cm and beyond, more than the 25cm on previous examination. UCEIS = 2 + 2 + 3 = 7.
pathology_result:
The biopsies from both sites are rather poorly orientated, hindering assessment. Both sites show crypt architecture distortion, in places imparting a villiform appearance. There is mild expansion of the lamina propria by chronic inflammation which appears diffuse with some variability due to associated oedema.

There is associated patchy mild active inflammation in the form of occasional crypt abscesses. Possible ulcer slough is noted in the background. Paneth cell metaplasia is present focally at both sites.

No obvious viral inclusions are seen. CMV IHC negative. No granulomas or parasites. There is no dysplasia or malignancy.

Comment
The features overall are in keeping with established diagnosis of UC. The patchiness of active inflammation may be a result of medical therapy. The degree of inflammation appears less than noted endoscopically.
ct_result:
Suspected mild left sided colitis with evidence of mural thickening and fat stranding best demonstrated in the proximal sigmoid colon. Distally the bowel is empty with right-sided faecal loading. Fat deposition in the distal sigmoid and rectum. No evidence of bowel obstruction. Terminal ileum is grossly normal.

Comment: Mild active on chronic left-sided colitis / UC distribution. No complicating factors identified, specifically no pneumoperitoneum.

diagnosis_note: Initially dx as UC but later colonoscopy shows granulomas and now favours CD

endoscopy_result: Confluent colitis to limit of insertion at 30cm. UCEIS = 2+2+2 = 6.
pathology_result:
These biopsies contain diffusely inflamed large bowel mucosa, with cryptitis, crypt abscesses, widespread ulceration and crypt withering, along with reactive mucosal architectural distortion.

The findings are of a severe active chronic colitis. Assuming infection has been excluded, the features would be consistent with IBD, with a pattern favouring UC. CMV immunohistochemistry negative.
ct_result:
No gross abnormality of unprepared bowel loops. Normal appendix and terminal ileum. Injection of the vasa recta with minor pericolic stranding affecting the colon from the hepatic flexure to the rectum.

Opinion:
Long contiguous segment of colitis from the transverse colon, down to the rectum. The differential would include infective causes, IBD and less likely, ischaemia.

baseline_gi_symptoms_desc: 2 weeks watery diarrhoea with occasional blood
endoscopy_result: There was mild patchy erythema and loss of vascular pattern in colon up until the transverse. In ascending and caecum there were discrete ulcers and the most marked inflammation was in the TI with congestion, oedema and ulceration as pictured.
pathology_result:
The biopsies from the terminal ileum show some fragments of normal small intestinal mucosa with well formed villous architecture but other fragments show villous atrophy with crypt hyperplasia and there are areas of mucosal ulceration. There is a patchy increase in the number of chronic inflammatory cells within the lamina propria and scattered crypt abscesses with cryptitis are noted. Granulomata are not identified.

These biopsies show fragments of large bowel mucosa with preservation of normal architecture but with mild mucin depletion. There is a patchy increase in the number of chronic inflammatory cells within the lamina propria and there is evidence of ulceration within the caecum and patchy active cryptitis with small crypt abscesses in the ascending colon. Granulomata are not identified.

The biopsies from the transverse and descending colon show no significant architectural distortion but there is a patchy increase in the number of chronic inflammatory cells and scattered neutrophils within the lamina propria which is variable between fragments. There is no significant active cryptitis and crypt abscesses are not identified. Granulomata are not identified.

The biopsies from the sigmoid and rectum show no significant architectural distortion. There is a mild patchy active inflammation of the lamina propria with a small number of neutrophils noted within some adjacent crypts but crypt abscesses are not identified and granulomata are not seen.

Conclusion
Overall, these biopsies show patchy active inflammation with ulceration predominantly involving the right colon and terminal ileum with minimal patchy active inflammation in the left colon. If an infective aetiology has been excluded, and in the absence of any relevant drug history, the histological features could represent Crohn's disease but they are by no means diagnostic.
mri_sb_result:
The terminal ileum is thickened over 25cm. This area demonstrates non contiguous abnormal contrast enhancement and restricted diffusion. At least two areas of luminal narrowing are demonstrated in the terminal ileum with associated proximal dilatation.

Multifocal Crohn's disease of the terminal ileum.

endoscopy_result: Severe inflammation to limit of insertion in distal transverse - UCEIS 7 (V2B2E3). Sigmoid relatively spared in keeping with partially treated UC.
pathology_result:
The biopsies from the transverse colon exhibit mild crypt architectural distortion with focal ulceration, scattered crypt abscesses but little in the way of cryptitis. There is a mild variable increase in chronic inflammatory cells in the lamina propria.

The biopsies from the descending colon are less markedly abnormal exhibiting only mild focal crypt architectural distortion with scattered foci of cryptitis.

A greater degree of crypt architectural distortion is seen in some of the biopsy only sigmoid colon were again crypt abscesses are seen and there is a suggestion of ulceration.

Crypt abscesses are also seen in the rectal biopsy but at this site there is a minimal crypt architectural distortion and a mild focal increase in chronic inflammatory cells in the lamina propria.

Conclusion
These sigmoidoscopic biopsies exhibit features of moderately active chronic UC, histologically most marked activity is seen in the biopsies from the transverse colon. The variability of inflammation is explained by medical therapy.

CMV inclusions are not seen and there is no dysplasia.

sample.name: cfDNA extracts 218
endoscopy_result: Completed to distal descending. Confluent colitis. UCEIS V2 B1 E2 = 5. Completed IV steroids. Plan to commence tofacitinib and home today.
pathology_result:
1. Proximal sigmoid: Sections show large bowel type mucosa with marked crypt architectural distortion in the form of bifid crypts and crypt loss. There is patchy moderate chronic inflammation within the lamina propria. Acute inflammation is present however mostly within the surface epithelium with only focal cryptitis and crypt abscess formation. Granulomas are not seen. Organisms are not seen. There is no evidence of dysplasia.

2. Rectal: Sections show large bowel type mucosa with marked crypt architectural distortion in the form of crypt loss. There is moderate chronic inflammation within the lamina propria which remains patchy. Cryptitis and crypt abscess formation appears more marked in these biopsies than those from the sigmoid. Granulomas are not seen. Organisms are not seen. There is no evidence of dysplasia.

Comment:
The appearances are those of a moderately active colitis and proctitis with marked crypt architectural distortion. The patchy distribution is likely secondary to partial treatment with IV steroids. The appearances are in keeping with moderately active, partially treated UC. There is no dysplasia.

endoscopy_result: Disease has extended to distal transverse. Normal mucosa coated with stool seen beyond. Mild-moderate inflammation, most active in distal 40cm - UCEIS V2B1E1 - 4
pathology_result:
All biopsies show similar features. There is mild to moderate acute and chronic inflammation. The lamina propria is expanded by plasma cells and lymphoid cells. There are foci of cryptitis, crypt abscesses and crypt distortion. There is also mucin depletion. There are no obvious CMV inclusions, and immunohistochemistry for CMV is negative. There is no dysplasia.

The features are those of a mild to moderately active ulcerative colitis worse in sigmoid and rectum.

baseline_gi_symptoms_desc: bo x4/day with some blood and mucus
steroids_detail: 1 dose IV steroids then converted to 40mg oral prednisolone OD reducing by 5mg/week
endoscopy_result: Moderately active, patchy left sided inflammation in keeping with partially treated disease. Most severe in sigmoid were superficial ulceration was seen (UCEIS 4).
pathology_result:
One of the biopsies from the transverse colon is normal, the others show mild crypt architectural distortion associated with a very mild focal increase in lamina propria inflammation. The biopsies from the descending colon are almost normal exhibiting any minimal lamina propria inflammation.

In contrast the biopsies from the sigmoid colon are more abnormal exhibiting marked crypt architectural distortion associated with mild goblet cell depletion and a variable at most moderate increase in chronic inflammatory cells in the lamina propria. There is a suggestion of ulceration however there is only minimal focal cryptitis and crypt abscesses are not observed.

The rectal biopsy is entirely normal showing no evidence of inflammation.

Conclusion
The features seen in the biopsy from the sigmoid colon are those of largely inactive treated chronic UC which correlates with the endoscopic findings. There is no dysplasia.

baseline_gi_symptoms_desc: Bloody stool 10x/day, tf from SJH failing IV steroids
endoscopy_result: There is active inflammation (moderate to severe) in the rectum and sigmoid which becomes less pronounced upwards with a normal looking colon after 50cm of insertion. Rectum UCEIS (2+1+2) = 5. Sigmoid UCEIS (1+1+1) = 3. Descending UCEIS (0+0+0) = 0.
pathology_result:
The biopsies from the descending colon appear normal.
The sigmoid and rectal biopsies show crypt architectural distortion, imparting a villiform appearance in places, with associated mucin depletion. The lamina propria shows diffuse chronic inflammation. There is associated moderate to severely active inflammation with foci of cryptitis, occasional crypt abscesses, areas of surface erosion and ulcer slough present. No viral inclusions, granulomas or parasites are seen. CMV immunohistochemistry is negative. There is no dysplasia or malignancy.

Comment
The features are in keeping with the established diagnosis of ulcerative colitis. Close correlation with clinical and endoscopic findings is advised. 

Colonic biopsies (descending, sigmoid and rectum) - Moderate to severely active chronic inflammation of the sigmoid colon and rectum.

endoscopy_result: Moderately inflamed to limit of insertion 40cm and beyond. Congested, erythematous and granular with patches of superficial ulceration.
pathology_result:
The sigmoid biopsies show a moderate and diffuse increase in lymphocytes and plasma cells within the lamina propria. There is cryptitis with multiple crypt abscesses and mucin depletion. The rectal biopsies also show diffuse chronic inflammation with some loss of the normal lamina propria gradient, however there is only focal cryptitis in these fragments. Crypt architectural distortion is not a prominent feature. Granulomas are not identified.

Comment: Both sets of biopsies show chronic and active inflammation, the latter moderate in the sigmoid colon but milder in the rectum. In the absence of an infective aetiology, the pattern of inflammation would be consistent with an initial presentation of IBD (in which the chronic architectural changes have yet to develop). The distribution may have been modified by IV steroids. There is no evidence of dysplasia.

endoscopy_result: 20mm sessile polyp in transverse lifted and resected. 12mm polyp in distal sigmoid removed using hot snare. Scattered diverticular disease and haemorrhoids.
pathology_result:
1) Polyp from transverse is tubulovillous adenoma with low and high grade dysplasia, no definite malignancy is seen but some concerning features. 
2) Polyp from sgimoid is tubulovillous adenoma with low grade dysplasia.

baseline_gi_symptoms_desc: Has been feeling very tired and "drained" along with noticing an increase in the frequency of his bowel movements.
endoscopy_result: Moderate inflammation to limit of insertion in distal transverse. Left colon SES-CD 6, rectum and distal sigmoid relatively spared SES-CD 3. Aphthous ulcers, congestion, erythema.
pathology_result:
Transverse to rectum: Examination overall shows good architectural preservation, but with mild distortion in the mid descending associated with some cryptitis and very occasional crypt abscess formation. There is minimal background focal cryptitis and one further small crypt abscess/degenerate crypt is seen within the more proximal biopsies. There is patchy lamina propria inflammation with some ulceration and deeper well formed epithelioid granulomas. No dysplasia or malignancy are seen.

The features are those of mild to focally moderately active Crohn's disease as stated clinically. The features appear worse in the biopsies from the mid descending colon with the rectum appearing more spared.
mri_pelvis_result:
Curvilinear intersphincteric high T2 signal at the left posterolateral margin of the anal canal with linear high T2 signal extending from the anal canal in the 6 o'clock position by approximately 1.5cm in keeping with a perianal fistula. This has not changed significantly in appearances when compared to previous study dated 03/11/2016.

Normal appearances of the rectum and sigmoid colon. No pelvic collections. Mesorectal reactive nodes.

Normal bone marrow signal. Normal appearances of the sacroiliac joints bilaterally.

Opinion:
Left low intersphincteric perianal fistula with 6 o'clock internal opening. No significant interval change from previous MRI of November 2016.
past_ibd_surgery_detail: EUA drainage of abscess/insertion of seton 08/05/2021

steroids_detail: 5mg oral prednisolone (maintenance for IBD and nephritis))

ct_result:
Abnormal appearing loops of small bowel with inflamed thickened walls, with luminal narrowing and mucosal enhancement and vascular injection - appearances are in keeping with inflammation. Loop of small bowel which appears most inflamed appears to be same loop of bowel which appeared inflamed on the previous MRI scan.
Section of small bowel just proximal to this within the distal pelvis is dilated up to 5.4cm.

There are further diseased appearing short segment of loops of bowel within the right iliac fossa, adjacent to the ileocecal valve. Again, this is seen on the previous MRI. A number of loops of bowel are tethered together in the right iliac fossa, but there is no definite evidence of fistulation.

Opinion:
Appearances are in keeping with active inflammatory small bowel Crohn's disease affecting the distal and terminal ileum, with evidence of upstream bowel dilatation secondary to this.
Possibility of an evolving fibrostenotic component, particularly given persisting dilatation since January.
Allowing for differencees in imaging modality, when compared with the MRI January, broadly similar appearances.

endoscopy_result: Macroscopically normal apart from mild blunting of the vascular pattern which is likely secondary to previous inflammation.
pathology_result:
The biopsies from all five sites are within normal limits. There was very mild crypt architectural distortion in the biopsy from the descending colon however this is minimal and may be a result of mild oedema. These is no significant inflammation, dysplasia or malignancy. Granulomas are not seen.

Colonoscopic biopsies - appearances are within normal limits, no active IBD.

endoscopy_result: Moderately active confluent colitis from rectum to hepatic flexure. Macroscopically appears as UC. V2B1U2 - UCEIS 5.
pathology_result:
The terminal ileal biopsies consists of superficial fragments of normal small bowel mucosa. The biopsies from the ascending colon consist of normal colonic mucosa.

In contrast of the biopsies from the transverse colon through to the rectum  are abnormal. They exhibit a moderate slightly variable increase in chronic inflammatory cells in the lamina propria with a degree of basal plasmacytosis. This is associated with cryptitis and relatively small numbers of crypt abscesses. There is only minimal focal goblet cell depletion and no significant crypt architectural distortion. The changes are slightly more pronounced in the rectal biopsies. Granulomata are not identified though further levels will be examined.

Conclusion
The features seen in these biopsies strongly favour a diagnosis of early inflammatory bowel disease over infection.

As this disease process is in an early stage of evolution and the histological changes are not marked there is uncertainty over further classification however I favour a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis.

sample.name: cfDNA extracts 242
endoscopy_result: Insertion to distal descending. Active Crohn's disease with relative rectal sparing.
pathology_result:
The biopsies from the sigmoid and rectum are abnormal exhibiting a moderate variable increase in chronic inflammatory cells and propria associated with scattered crypt abscesses, goblet cell depletion in the sigmoid colon but only mild crypt architectural distortion. There is evidence of ulceration in the sigmoid and overall the changes are less marked in the rectal biopsies which correlates with the endoscopic findings.

No CMV inclusions nor granulomata are seen.

Conclusion
The features are those of mildly active IBD, as noted above the changes are less marked in the rectum. While the appearance is in keeping with a clinical diagnosis of Crohn's disease on histologic features alone are not diagnostic. There is no dysplasia.

endoscopy_result:

Colon uniformly inflamed.  UCEIS 3 Mayo 1.

baseline_gi_symptoms_desc: diarrhoea for 7 weeks and abdo pain
endoscopy_result: Inflamed TI to degree of insertion (roughly 10cm) with ulceration and cobblestone mucosa. The rest of the colon was mildly inflamed with patches of erythema and erosions throughout.
pathology_result:
The biopsies from the terminal ileum contain some normal fragments of small bowel type mucosa as well as ulcer slough and inflamed granulation tissue. There are some fragments in which the normal mucosal architecture is lost and there is an increase of inflammation in the lamina propria with infiltration of neutrophils into epithelium. No granulomas are seen.

The colonic biopsies are all abnormal. They show colonic mucosa with a normal mucosal architecture but showing a patchy increase in acute and chronic inflammation in the lamina propria with focal active inflammation with scattered cryptitis and crypt abscesses. A single rather ill-formed granuloma is present in the biopsies from the descending colon.

The appearances are those of active inflammatory bowel disease with a pattern and distribution more in keeping with Crohn's disease than ulcerative colitis. The disease is worse in the terminal ileum where there is evidence of severe activity with ulceration.

Colonoscopic biopsy series - Severely active inflammatory bowel disease, pattern favours Crohn's disease
mri_sb_result:
The lack of intra-abdominal fat hinders interpretation. However, there is a long segment of abnormal TI / distal ileum with severe abnormal small bowel loops in the pelvis. It is difficult to accurately measure the length of the affected small bowel, but I suspect it is at least 50cm. The distal few cms of TI appears focally thickened. These loops demonstrate abnormal enhancement following contrast and also demonstrate restricted diffusion.

Small pool of free fluid within the pelvis which is an abnormal finding in a young male.

The liver, spleen, pancreas, adrenals and both kidneys outline normally.

Small volume reactive lymph nodes in the right side of the abdomen.

Opinion:
Presumed Crohn's disease affecting a long segment of pelvic and distal ileum.
No significant small bowel abnormality. The terminal ileum is unremarkable with no convincing restricted diffusion or abnormal enhancement.

The rectal biopsies exhibit slight crypt shortening but are otherwise also normal, there is no evidence of inflammation throughout.

endoscopy_result: There was moderate inflammation from rectum to beyond limit of insertion at splenic flexure. UCEIS - 2+1+2 = 5.
pathology_result:
All of these biopsies are uniformly abnormal, there is a diffuse moderate
increase in chronic inflammatory cells in lamina propria associated with goblet
cell depletion, crypt elongation, cryptitis and scattered crypt abscesses. There
is little in the way of crypt architectural distortion. Granulomata are not
identified.

Conclusion

These biopsies exhibit features of moderately active inflammatory bowel disease.
The relative lack of crypt architectural distortion is presumed to reflect the
relatively short history, despite this the overall features favour a diagnosis
of ulcerative colitis. There is no evidence of dysplasia in these biopsies.

baseline_gi_symptoms_desc: back pain, looser stools, nausea, weight loss
endoscopy_result: Completed to caecum but unable to intubate TI. There was a few scattered diverticulae in the sigmoid colon but no inflammation. There was a very small segment at 15cm where there may have been smooth muscle hypertrophy but no narrowing or tortuosity. Sessile polyp removed from distal sigmoid.
pathology_result: The sigmoid polyp is hyperplastic in nature. The remaining biopsies comprise normal colonic and rectal mucosa. There is no evidence of IBD.
ct_result:
Generalised thickening, inflammatory changes and fat wrapping around the proximal sigmoid colon. There are two areas of extramural inflammatory phlegmon which contain some gas, both of which track from the sigmoid and are inseparable from nearby distal ileal loops. In addition, much of the collapsed colon and the distal ileum demonstrates mural fatty deposition. Taken together with the history above, these appearances raise the concern of acute on chronic IBD, with complex coloenteric fistulation. Although there are a small number of colonic diverticula present, these are thought less likely to be driving the current apperances. At present, there is no enhancing fluid collection. No free gas. The unprepared small bowel appears unremakable, with no dilated segments to suggest chronic stricturing.

Opinion:
Appearances suggest complex IBD with active inflammation and coloenteric fistulation. Sacroiliac ankylosis also noted.
diagnosis_note: Initially though diverticulosis but subsequently diagnosed as CD on basis of imaging

endoscopy_result: Severe inflammation to sigmoid and beyond, denuded mucosa, 1.5cm polyp.
pathology_result:
The biopsies from the sigmoid colon and the rectum exhibit the features of moderately active chronic ulcerative colitis. There is crypt architectural distortion with villiform transformation of the mucosal surface associated with ulceration in the sigmoid colon (CMV inclusions are not seen), crypt loss, cryptitis but no evidence of crypt abscess formation. Overall goblet cells are well preserved. The degree of inflammation is worse in the sigmoid colon as compared to the rectum there is no evidence of dysplasia in these biopsies.

These superficial biopsies from the sigmoid polyp exhibit the features of a tubulovillous adenoma exhibiting low-grade dysplasia. There is no evidence of inflammation in these superficial biopsies.

mri_sb_result:
Small bowel obstruction secondary to stricture at the ileocolic anastomosis. The stricture is associated with some abnormal bowel wall thickening, restricted diffusion and mild enhancement. This extends over a distance of approximately 5cm.
There is slight thickening of the small bowel proximal to this with some restricted diffusion suggesting active disease. This extends over a distance of approximately 10cm.
Restricted diffusion in the proximal ascending colon in keeping with involvement.

Allowing for collapsed proximal small bowel loops no definite evidence of disease elsewhere although on recent CT there did appear to be some active disease in a loop of proximal ileum.

Simple liver cyst. The rest of the abdominal and pelvic organs are normal.

Comment
Small bowel obstruction secondary to stricture at the ileocolic anastomosis. This appears to be a combination of active and chronic disease.
Active disease in the distal ileum and ascending colon.

endoscopy_result: Confluent moderate active inflammation to limit of insertion in the distal descending. UCEIS 5.
pathology_result:
The sigmoid biopsies show a moderate and largely diffuse increase in lymphocytes and plasma cells within the lamina propria, including basal plasmacytosis. There is cryptitis with mucin depletion. The crypts are shortened and distorted and there is focal Paneth cell metaplasia. The rectal biopsies show milder and more patchy chronic and active inflammation with crypt distortion. Granulomas are not identified.

Comment: The appearances are in keeping with the history of ulcerative colitis. There is moderate activity in the sigmoid colon and milder activity in the rectum, presumably representing a partial response to treatment. CMV inclusions are not identified. There is no evidence of dysplasia.

medication_comments: Patient sampled before starting IV steroids.
endoscopy_result: There are multiple superficial apthous ulcers throughout the left colon as far as the transverse. These are largest in the sigmoid and descending colon. Intervening mucosa (and that of the right colon and TI) is normal. Patchy apthous ulceration highly suggestive of Crohn's.
pathology_result:
TI biopsy: Examination shows superficial pieces of unremarkable small bowel mucosa.

Caecum: Examination shows normal large bowel mucosa.

Transverse to rectum: Examination shows increasing acute and chronic inflammation in a patchy distribution with some more normal fragments and some fragments of ulcer. The background also shows focal acute and chronic inflammation with cryptitis and occasional crypt abscess formation. The architecture is largely preserved outwith the areas of ulceration, with only mild distortion seen in some of the more distal biopsies. No granulomas are seen. The appearances are worst in the sigmoid and show relative sparing of the rectum.

The features are those of a patchy active colitis with ulceration. The features are predominantly acute in nature in this biopsy series and whilst suspicious of Crohn's disease I cannot entirely exclude the possibility that this represents infection or a drugs reaction and careful this must be excluded in the first instance.
mri_sb_result:
Thickening of the distal colon from the distal sigmoid to the mid descending colon with restricted diffusion. Associated adjacent fat stranding. Further mild restricted diffusion of the visualised ascending colon and cecum and therefore pan colonic involvement should also be considered.

Normal transit of oral contrast through the small bowel.
Grossly normal appearances of the small bowel which is of normal calibre with no focal thickening, strictures or segmental dilatation Normal appearances of the terminal ileum with no restricted diffusion.
No collection, significant free fluid or fistulation.

Normal appearances of the upper abdominal viscera. No significant adnexal masses.
Visualised lung bases are clear. 
Normal signal returned of the visualised bone marrow. Normal sacroiliac joints.

Opinion:
Involvement of the distal colon from the mid-descending colon to the distal sigmoid.
Further mild restricted diffusion of the visualised ascending colon and cecum raises the possibility of pancolonic involvement. 
Grossly normal appearances of the small bowel and normal appearances of the terminal ileum.

endoscopy_result: Colonoscopy reveals that there is still evidence of patchy linear ulceration throughout the colon with relative rectal sparing. The changes are generally very focal with focal ulcers sitting in areas of otherwise normal mucosa. However in the proximal transverse and sigmoid there are two areas where the inflammation is more generalised. In the proximal transverse this corresponds to a very oedematous area with some reduction in calibre (inflammatory stricture). The hepatic flexure, ascending and caecum less badly affected though again there is patchy aphthous ulceration here too. IC valve and TI normal. Disappointing response to anti TNF. Endoscopic photographs supplied.
pathology_result:
Colonoscopic biopsies
1. Terminal ileum
2. Caecum
3. Ascending
4. Transverse
5. Descending
6. Sigmoid
7. Rectum

Macroscopy

1. Three fragments
2, 3, 5 - 7. Each biopsy consists of 2 fragments
4. Seven fragments
                                
The terminal ileal biopsies consist of normal small bowel mucosa.
                                
There is evidence of ulceration in all of the biopsies from the caecum through to the sigmoid colon. The intact mucosa in the caecum and ascending colon exhibits only a focal increase in chronic inflammatory cells in the lamina propria with an occasional crypt abscess in the caecum. The biopsies from the transverse colon consist predominately of ulcer base with only minimal inflammation in the small amount of intact mucosa present. The biopsies from the descending colon exhibit only a mild increase in chronic inflammatory cells in lamina propria, lamina propria inflammation is somewhat more prominent in the biopsies from the sigmoid were there are also very occasional crypt abscesses.

The rectal biopsies contain a single crypt abscess and exhibit only a minimal focal increase in lamina propria inflammation.

There is no evidence of significant crypt architectural distortion in any of these biopsies. Neither CMV inclusions nor granulomata are seen. There is also no evidence of dysplasia in any of these biopsies.
 
Conclusion

These colonic biopsies confirm the presence of multifocal ulceration throughout the colon with only mild inflammation of the adjacent mucosa. The features seen are in keeping with the clinical diagnosis of Crohn's disease but on their own are not diagnostic.
mri_sb_result: Ongoing active left colitis. Progressive perianal disease with complex fistula, enlarging horseshoe abscesses and right puborectalis inflammatory change.

endoscopy_result: Only very minor proctitis. V1+B0+E1 = 2; Mayo score 1. Sigmoid and descending colon looked normal.
pathology_result:
The biopsies from the descending and sigmoid colon all exhibit a mild diffuse increase in chronic inflammatory cells in lamina propria associated with occasional crypt abscesses and foci of cryptitis. There is no evidence of crypt architectural distortion.

The rectal biopsies are largely normal, there is only a minimal focal increase in chronic inflammatory cells in the lamina propria with no evidence of crypt inflammation or crypt architectural distortion.

Conclusion
The established diagnosis of UC is noted. These current biopsies exhibit only minimal inflammation with the degree of rectal sparing and no evidence of architectural distortion. The features though not specific are in keeping with minimally active IBD. There is no evidence of dysplasia in any of these biopsies.

1-3, 5, 6, 8, 9. The ileal biopsies  are slightly small and superficial appear
to show mild villous blunting and a patchy increase in the number of
intraepithelial lymphocytes.  There is no significant active inflammation and
granulomata are not identified.

The colonic biopsies all show similar histological features. There is no
significant architectural distortion but there is a generalised increase in the
number of chronic inflammatory cells within the superficial lamina propria
including some macrophages.  Intraepithelial lymphocytosis is noted throughout the colonic biopsies involving both  the surface epithelium and the crypt epithelium. Occasional intraepithelial neutrophils are noted but there is no significant active cryptitis and there are no crypt abscesses. Crypt epithelial apoptosis is not prominent and there is no subepithelial collagen band. Granulomata are not identified.

The overall features are those of a lymphocytic colitis with involvement of the
terminal ileum. There are no features of chronic idiopathic inflammatory bowel disease.

ileum

There is no significant increase in chronic inflammatory cells. No granulomas or parasites are seen. There is no dysplasia or malignancy.

There is no dysplasia or malignancy.

distortion and crypt loss with Paneth cell metaplasia.  There is no significant inflammation in the descending colon fragments.  One of the fragments from the sigmoid contains an area consistent with healing ulceration.

endoscopy_result: From the rectum to the limit of insertion there was moderately active ulcerative colitis - UCEIS = 2+2+2 = 6. Representative biopsies including for CMV.
pathology_result:
The biopsies from the descending and sigmoid colon exhibit similar features, there is a mild to moderate slightly variable increase in chronic inflammatory cells lamina propria with marked crypt loss and crypt architectural distortion and only minimal cryptitis. There is a suggestion of ulceration biopsies from sigmoid colon. A single isolated giant cell is seen in one of the biopsies from the descending colon.

The rectal biopsies exhibit more marked inflammation of lamina propria, again there is marked crypt loss and crypt architectural distortion. Cryptitis is more prominent at this site however crypt abscesses are not seen. CMV inclusions are not identified. There is no evidence of dysplasia in any of these biopsies.

Conclusion
These biopsies exhibit the features of chronic ulcerative colitis with marked crypt loss, overall there is a relative lack of active inflammation suggesting a degree of response to medical therapy. Cryptitis is however present in the rectal biopsy.

These biopsies is that the features of chronic ulcerative colitis are at least
histologically the changes are similar in both the sigmoid and rectum. There is only minimal histological evidence of activity. There is no evidence of dysplasia in these biopsies.

mri_sb_result:

Proximal to the stricture, there is mild prominence of small bowel but no obstruction. Terminal ileal Crohn's which is slightly worse than the MR of 2016.
Overall the appearances are significantly better than the MR in 2015.

pathology_result:
The biopsies from the caecum to the descending colon are of normal colonic mucosa and show no architectural distortion and no evidence of inflammation.

The biopsies from the sigmoid colon and rectum are all abnormal. They show colonic mucosa with disturbed mucosal architecture with loss of crypts from large amounts of the tissue, a focally villiform surface and evidence of ulceration. There is evidence of muscularis mucosae reduplication in some of the better orientated fragments and a diffuse increase in inflammation in the lamina propria with evidence of a basal plasmacytosis. There is some evidence of cryptitis and crypt abscess formation and some vaguely granulomatous areas of inflammation associated with dissolving crypts. No CMV inclusions are seen.

The appearances are of severely active IBD with a pattern and distribution entirely in keeping with UC.

ct_result:
Surgical sutures at the caecum. History of Crohn's disease noted from prior radiology reports.

Multiple dilated small bowel loops, measuring up to 4.1cm at the distal ileum, with at least three points where the ileal wall thickens and the calibre of the bowel narrows significantly in keeping with focal stenoses, all of these are at similar points compared to prior. The most distal segment of focal ileal wall thickening at the terminal ileum demonstrates adjacent inflammatory stranding, and appears to be causing the upstream dilatation of the small bowel loops. No perforation.
No free gas or discrete collection.

Multiple jejunal diverticula noted. No frank diverticulitis.
Moderate quiescent diverticular disease of the sigmoid colon.
Remainder of the unprepared large bowel is grossly normal.

Small volume gallstones. Gallbladder otherwise normal. No intra or extrahepatic duct dilatation. NO ductal stone.
Simple right renal cysts.
Remainder of the upper abdominal survey are otherwise normal.

Mild bibasal atelectasis, the imaged lung bases are otherwise grossly clear.

L1 inferior endplate fracture, new from prior, likely osteoporotic in nature and is nonacute. Mild degenerative changes of the lower lumbar spine particularly at L4/L5. No destructive bony abnormality identified.

Opinion:
Dilated ileal loops with a few transition points of mural thickening and narrowing the small bowel calibre in keeping with stenoses secondary to Crohn's. The most distal segment of focal ileal thickening at the terminal ileum appears to be causing upstream dilatation of the small bowel loops.

Simple liver cyst. Normal kidneys, right adrenals and pancreas. This slightly elongated spleen at 15cm. Indeterminate left adrenal lesion. Suggest MRI adrenals once the patient has recovered from acute episode. No abdominal or pelvic nodal enlargement. No destructive bone lesion. No significant abnormality of the visualised lung bases.

endoscopy_result: Severe inflammation to proximal sigmoid, obliterated vascular pattern, luminal bleeding and deep ulceration (UCEIS 8). Appearances improve slightly in descending with more superficial ulceration. Inflammation extends to mid-transverse with relatively normal mucosa beyond mid-transverse. Biopsy series taken as above. Biopsies also taken for CMV. For IFX and azathioprine as IP.
pathology_result:
The caecal biopsies exhibit mild focal crypt architectural distortion only, there is no evidence of inflammation. The biopsies from the ascending colon in addition contain very occasional small crypt abscesses. The biopsies from the transverse colon contain more definite crypt abscesses and exhibit a greater degree of crypt architectural distortion but this is still relatively focal and mild and there is minimal lamina propria inflammation.

The biopsies from the descending colon through to the rectum are more abnormal exhibiting a more marked diffuse increase in chronic inflammatory cells in the lamina propria associated with scattered crypt abscesses and foci of cryptitis associated with goblet cell depletion and focal crypt architectural distortion. There is evidence of ulceration in the biopsies from the descending colon and rectum. CMV inclusions are not seen on routine H&E staining.

Granulomata are not identified and there is no evidence of dysplasia.

Conclusion

The biopsies from the descending colon through to the rectum exhibit features of chronic severe active inflammatory bowel disease with scanty changes seen more proximally. The pattern is that of ulcerative colitis as suspected endoscopically.

sample.name: 291 1 in 10
ct_result:
The pancreas does appear swollen with mild peripancreatic stranding, suggestive of mild pancreatitis.
No gallstones identified.  No evidence of biliary dilatation.
No evidence of significant fluid collection.
No evidence of upper gastrointestinal perforation.
The most significant pathology is however thought to relate to distal small bowel, with areas of fibrostenotic and active Crohn's disease, with skip lesions involving the distal 30 cm of small bowel.
Moderate amounts of pelvic fluid are present.
No other significant findings.
Upper abdominal organs are otherwise essentially normal.

Summary
Active Crohn disease superimposed on fibrostenotic disease within the distal 30 cm of small bowel.
Suggestion of mild pancreatic swelling
past_medical_history_detail: Perforated duodenal ulcer with open repair 2012

ct_result: Approx 20cm active terminal and distal ileitis with short stricture/narrowing and associated upstream dilatation

endoscopy_result: Mild patchy rectal inflammation. Most marked abnormality in sigmoid with significant active colitis - congestion, oedema, luminal narrowing and blood. Extensive mucopurulent exude in the sigmoid, patches of more normal mucosa and preservation of architecture. Limit of insertion 60cm.
pathology_result: Moderate sigmoid colitis with minimal crypt architectural distortion in the sigmoid and rectum. Appearances could be in keeping with the clinical impression of IBDU.
mri_sb_result: Pancolitis from caecal pole to proximal sigmoid. Significant restricted diffusion in keeping with active disease. No small bowel disease.

endoscopy_result: Moderately-severely active colitis to splenic flexure (UCEIS 7), worse in rectum/sigmoid. Biopsies taken as above. To proceed to infliximab.
pathology_result:
1-3. The biopsies from all sites are heavily inflamed and include fragments of ulcer base and ulcer slough.

There is mild crypt architectural distortion and crypt shortening. The lamina propria contains a diffuse increase in chronic inflammatory cells including several lymphoid aggregates.

There is moderate to severe active inflammation with widespread cryptitis and foci of ulceration at all sites. No granulomas or parasites are seen. No viral inclusions are identified. CMV immunohistochemistry is negative. There is no dysplasia or malignancy.

The appearances would be supportive of a diagnosis of moderate to severely  active ulcerative colitis, provided infectious and drug causes of been excluded clinically.

1-3. Colonic biopsies (descending, sigmoid, rectum) - Moderate to severely 
active chronic inflammation
